mdRecord.dcterms:title: Letter, George Washington to Robert Lewis, 1799 August 17
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Washington, George, 1732-1799
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Washington writes that Lewis failed to endorse Ariss's note for rent -- Washington will give Kercheval extra time to pay if he has really been unfortunate in crops, not that he can easily afford it -- Mount Vernon has "more working negroes by a full moiety than can be employed in the farming system" -- sale of his lands barely keeps him afloat -- "to sell the over-plus [of negroes] I cannot because I am principled against this kind of traffic in the human species. - To hire them out, is almost as bad, because they could not be disposed of in families to any advantage, and to disperse the families I have an aversion." -- he is determined to settle plantations on some of his western lands, but knows most of it is leased with encumbrances -- questions Lewis as to value, availability, etc. of his western lands for this purpose -- drought has ruined oats and possibly corn at Mt. Vernon -- poor grass compels him to sell some of asses, so he asks whether there is any market for them in Fauquier? -- Washington is glad that Lawrence Lewis has recovered some of his health -- the postscript relates that he sends the letter under cover to Mr. Bush at Winchester or at Fauquier Courthouse. Autograph letter signed, 4 pages [AR, 1954 lists a cover with this, but seems to be missing now], silked. Name on original manuscript appears as "G. Washington".
